In the past, the cost and time required to make quality video content was prohibitive. Marketing teams everywhere are exploring how AI can help them save time and budget in the video production process, while simultaneously boosting creativity. We’ll get into the ways AI tools can help marketing teams create videos faster, and outline some apps and platforms to try. Let’s go. Ways to streamline the video production process with AI Marketing teams are enlisting the help of AI video production tools to stand out and transform content into new media formats — here’s how. Ideation There’s a lot of pressure on creative teams to develop video content for different departments, concepts, and goals. Product videos have specific considerations and look much different than videos for the careers, customer education, or advertising teams. AI tools can help video teams brainstorm, visualize ideas, and put together scripts. Story/concept Marketing teams have already started using AI brainstorming tools like ChatGPT, NotionAI, and Google Gemini to generate ideas, and they’re using the output as a jumping-off point to direct their efforts. See here how you can use ChatGPT to quickly develop an idea into a story or concept, with suggestions for each frame you can later use in a shot list. Try these prompts with a generative AI tool and see how quickly your imagination can take off: “We want to create a product launch video to showcase the features, use cases, and initial customer reactions and encourage viewers to sign up to receive a sample product. The product is [describe your product here]. Please map out a script for the voiceover and a shot list for a 30 second video, along with suggestions for music, transitions, and lighting.” “Please transform this written interview into a case study video format with shot suggestions, intro copy, and a call to action at the end to read the whole case study.” Script And many marketing teams are using generative AI writing tools like Jasper.ai and Writesonic to create simple scripts to use as a starting point. Consider taking existing content, like blog posts, ebooks, and reports, and using generative AI tools to turn them into video scripts. When creating scripts with AI tools, remember to include: Voice and tone suggestions Intended video length Campaign goals Audience Pre-production During pre-production, AI tools are most helpful for two things — creative development and administrative tasks. Creative teams can use AI to help generate storyboards, illustrate potential video concepts visually, and experiment with visual styles. Assistant directors or project managers can cut down on time spent on the administrative elements of pre-production like call sheets, scheduling, and shot lists. Project planning To get a video from idea to launch, it takes lots of team members from different departments, and they all need to be aligned from the start. AI tools can automatically put together campaign timelines, assign tasks to individuals with deadlines, and help video teams handle more projects at a time with fewer headaches. Art direction Art directors are using AI tools to explore ideas, visualize concepts, and work through potential stories — without spending months developing minimum viable products (MVPs) to see if they’ll work. Michael Kuroda, a Production Manager at HouseFishBalloon, tested out adding AI to the art direction process and shares, “​​Where I would usually spend hours mocking up picture variations, trying different color schemes, and adding environmental depth, I can now spend that time adding effects and billboards. As a result, this new painting…is much more lively than my previous attempt while simultaneously taking much less time.” Source: House Fish Balloon Midjourney is an AI text to image generator, like StableDiffusion, that lets the user iterate on previously generated images, making it easy to show a variety of visual styles that stakeholders can choose from. Deforum is an AI image and animation generator that lets users quickly create simple animations out of text queries. Source: Midjourney Storyboarding Storyboarding is one of the most exciting places to use AI for video production. AI tools are ideal for visualizing video concepts without taking up too much creative bandwidth, giving brand teams more room to play with ideas and test out more of their “outside the box” pitches. Arturo Tedeschi, an Italian artist, is using DALL-E to transform descriptive text from classic movies into visual storyboards for films. “The art of storyboarding deserves attention not only for graphic quality…but as a creative bridge between screenplay and film, as a link between language and images. Cutting-edge systems like DALL-E have learned the relationship between image and text,” shared Tedeschi. Source: designboom. Location scouting Video teams can enlist ChatGPT and other tools as a research assistant. Ask conversational AI tools which locations are best for video shoots based on permit requirements, weather conditions, availability, and any other considerations you’re thinking about to get a sample list. Then, go through the proposed locations and fact-check, or draw inspiration from the ideas. Shot list Use AI tools to turn a script into a shot list, making sure to instruct generative AI tools to capture the flow and keep it within the desired timeframe. StudioBinder is an AI tool that generates shot lists and it’s specifically designed for filmmaking. Call sheet and scheduling Rather than spending hours manually creating call sheets, prepping scheduling emails, and creating workback schedules, set up AI prompts to automate administrative tasks. Here’s an example prompt for an AI-generated call sheet: “Take all characters from the pages of this script and organize them into a call sheet with character, actor name, time needed, scenes to be rehearsed and schedule, and location.” Production AI generated video production is new and companies are still working through some of the early bugs, like unnatural voice overs. And there’ll always be a place for on-camera talent. But for certain video styles like animations, talking head videos, avatar videos, social media clips, and more, AI tools and templates can align creative teams and provide first drafts that are easier to edit. AI generated videos AI video generation tools like InVideo, Pictory, and RawShorts can fully create a video from start to finish, using AI-generated voice-over (VO), avatars, stock footage, video templates, and animations to dynamically communicate ideas. For Staff-Picked filmmaker Paul Trillo, the draw of AI is in its aesthetic ticks — and the new visual style that’s being created as it goes mainstream. “I’m leaning into the natural aesthetic that the AI videos are creating, rather than pushing against it,” he says. “Right now, it’s more interesting as its own aesthetic.” Explainer videos for newsletters, internal sharing, or social media Explainer videos can outline new product features, teach a concept to help an audience grow, or deliver company updates. Typically, these kinds of videos are composed of talking head footage interspersed with images and other short clips — but AI tools like Synthesia can save teams the hours of filming a busy VP or CEO talking, and just create an avatar to deliver the script instead. Social media videos Social media videos (and video ads) are excellent at grabbing attention whether they’re made for Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, or TikTok. RawShorts, InVideo, Canva and Pictory all have AI-powered options for social media video creation. AI video tools AI video tools help out at a certain point in the video generation process, like turning text to video or adding animation. Synthesia is an AI video generator where users can upload their scripts and have them read by one of 140 diverse avatars. The team at Forecast, a project management tool, is using AI to build out Forecast Academy, a learning library with multimedia educational tools — now featuring AI-generated educational videos made with Synthesia. “Before, producing videos was a long, multi-staged process, now many of those stages are condensed within a single software,” shared Ryan McMeekin on the Forecast Academy team. Source: Forecast Academy InVideo is an AI text to video generator that helps marketers create video ads and social media videos. It also helps teams create video scripts, and quickly repurpose blog content into videos. AI video templates Video templates can serve as a storyboard, guide for timing or cuts, or the first draft of a video. Canva has free customizable video templates (like Vimeo!) and AI-powered writing and image generation tools built right into the platform, along with creative approval processes and collaborative team features. And Raw Shorts has video templates that you can use in their AI video maker. Source: Raw Shorts AI visual effects Snapchat and Instagram changed the game with responsive augmented reality filters, and now some of the technology behind VR/AR is coming to video production through AI tools. One tool, Gen-1, which writer Loz Blain refers to as “like DALL-E for moving pictures” can apply visual video effects to video files and generate new videos in different styles and formats. AI audio syncing and sound effects Sound engineers have been waiting for this one. AI tools can now match audio up to video and provide suggested background noises and other sound effects. Here’s an example of a Soundify video with AI-generated audio. Post-production We’ve only begun to explore the impact of AI tools on post-production and video editing, but organizations like the Associated Press, that manage thousands of hours of live footage every year, are already seeing the benefits of AI-automated video management. AP’s VP of News, Sandy MacIntyre is spearheading efforts to use AI to automatically pull out great photos and sound-bites, and reduce overall production ‘grunt work’, as a way of “liberating people to do more creative things with the editing and production time.” The AP team has found that AI-powered speech-to-text transcription has been working well so far, but sentiment analysis and video searchability have a ways to go. Video editing In the video editing process, AI-powered tools help teams with color correction, inpainting, background removal, jump cuts, sound and voiceover (VO) editing, and much more. ElevenLabs is a text-to-speech AI software that takes a written script and instantly turns it into a natural-sounding voice-over to use in videos. “Text-to-speech AI tools are powerful for timing scripts and making sure everything sounds good before going into a recording,” says Odette Santos, Principal Cinematographer at HubSpot. AI-powered video editors like Runway ML have video inpainting, effective video background removers, and a text-to-color grade function that lets video editors color grade through queries like “make this clip look like an old silent film” or “make the clip cooler-toned”. AI tools can also automatically create jump cuts, remove silence, speed up scenes, and cut commentary in video and podcasts. They can also remove bad takes or identify the best version of a clip. Timebolt, an AI video editor, even has an “Umcheck” feature that helps cut out filler words, and a tool to cut recorded Zoom meetings into condensed, distilled explainers that make for great product walkthroughs and internal training videos. Voice over During the voice-over phase, there are a few ways to use AI tools: Generate a voice-over track from scratch using an AI voice. Generate foreign language voice overs using AI. Smooth out or edit voice overs — cut “ums”, dead air, etc. Think about your audience and region when choosing an AI-generated voice. Audio cleanup Adobe Podcast is an AI-powered podcast production platform that includes powerful AI speech enhancement features, making subpar audio clear as day — and it lets users edit audio by cutting and reordering transcript text. Music and sound beds Music composition can take a long time, even just to search for royalty-free sounds for quick product videos. With AI tools like Orb Producer Suite, you can create your own music or background sounds, or edit the sound throughout a video file for consistency. Color-grading Want to achieve the Wes Anderson color grading effect in your next video? Wes Anderson-style videos have cropped up across social media in a delightful way, showcasing creativity. Even brands like Paramount Pictures have jumped on the Wes Anderson trend. AI tools can now copy the color grading from images and apply them to video, and automatically adjust an entire file with a new style. Rotoscoping “Things like rotoscoping and inpainting, which took a lot of hours, computing power, and focus, are now possible in a browser with limited technical ability. We’re just seeing the beginnings of how workflows will be transformed,” shared Matthew Watkins, Creative Director at HubSpot. Logging and tagging Logging and tagging is one of the more technical aspects of video production. AI-powered content analysis tools like Google’s Video AI require the user to train the model, but then they can create custom tags and access rich analytics — then more quickly create highlight reels, clips, and more. Repurposing and distribution The power of video lies in its ability to spread far and wide and reach new audiences. Creating, editing, and finishing videos isn’t the end of the road, but the beginning of the distribution process. Let’s look at how AI can help get your video content in front of more folks. Transforming content between media formats Work smarter, not harder. Turn podcasts into videos, add summary videos along with written content, and create explainer videos for new product features. Cutting and resharing videos for different channels Take long-form video content and repurpose it for social media — create a few Reels, TikTok videos, or YouTube Shorts from every longer video. Think about where your audience lives online, though, and don’t just create new social video content because you can. Or, turn educational videos into courses and join clips together to create longer lessons, like Forecast Academy is doing. Creating trailers and short-form clips Video content performs extremely well — videos help increase traffic, drive leads, and drive better engagement. Cut quick clips, highlight reels and trailers from longer videos using Vimeo AI to use for short-form content like social media video ads, promotional assets for a big campaign, or even in your internal video communication strategy. Artificial intelligence (AI) video generators are transforming the way businesses and content creators approach video production. In this comprehensive guide, we’ll explore the world of AI video generation and how it can help you create stunning, professional-quality videos with ease. What Is AI Video Generation? AI video generation is the process of using artificial intelligence to automatically create, edit, and personalize videos. This cutting-edge technology leverages machine learning algorithms, computer vision, and natural language processing (NLP) to understand and generate text-to-video content with minimal human intervention. AI video generators can create videos from scratch based on text prompts, images, or even existing video footage. They can also enhance and transform existing videos by adding special effects, changing backgrounds, or even altering the appearance of people within the video. The possibilities are endless with AI video generation. You can create engaging explainer videos, stunning visual stories, personalized marketing content, and much more. How AI Video Generators Work To understand how AI video generators work, let’s take a closer look at the underlying technology and the typical content creation workflow involved in creating an AI-generated video. The Technology Behind AI Video Creation At the core of AI video generation lies a combination of advanced technologies, including: Machine learning: AI video makers use machine learning algorithms to analyze vast amounts of data and learn patterns, styles, and techniques. This allows them to generate new videos that mimic human-created content. Computer vision: Computer vision enables AI systems to interpret visual information. It allows AI video generators to recognize objects, scenes, and people within videos, making it possible to intelligently manipulate and enhance the content. Natural language processing: NLP enables AI video generators to understand and process human language. This allows users to provide text-based instructions or scripts, which the AI can then translate into visual content. Generative adversarial networks (GANs): GANs are a type of deep learning architecture that consists of two competing neural networks — a generator and a discriminator. The generator creates new content while the discriminator evaluates its authenticity. Through this adversarial process, AI video generators can create highly realistic and diverse content. When you use an AI video generator, you typically start by providing an input, such as a text prompt, an image, or existing video footage. The AI system then analyzes this input and uses its training to generate a new video based on your specifications. The AI video generator will consider factors such as composition, pacing, transitions, and visual style to create a cohesive and engaging video. It can also incorporate additional elements, such as music, voiceovers, and special effects, to enhance the overall experience. Throughout the generation process, the AI system continuously evaluates and refines the video to ensure it meets the desired quality and style. This iterative approach allows AI video generators to create highly polished and professional-looking videos with minimal human intervention. Benefits of Using AI Video Generators Now that you have a better understanding of how AI video creators work, let’s explore some of the key benefits they offer. Enhance Efficiency and Productivity One of the most significant advantages of using AI video generators is the boost in efficiency and productivity they provide. With AI video generators, you can streamline the entire creation and editing process. These tools automate many of the tedious and repetitive tasks involved in video production, such as keyframe animation, color correction, and audio syncing. This allows you to focus on the creative aspects of your video, such as crafting compelling stories and engaging your audience. They also enable you to create videos at scale. Instead of spending days or weeks on a single video, you can generate multiple videos in a fraction of the time. This is particularly valuable for businesses and content creators who need to regularly produce a high volume of content. Save Time and Resources In addition to boosting efficiency, AI video generators can also help you save time and resources. Hiring a professional video production team can quickly become a costly endeavor, especially for small businesses and freelancers with limited budgets. AI video generators level the playing field by making professional-quality video creation accessible to everyone. Many AI video tools offer affordable subscription plans, or even free options, allowing you to create stunning videos without breaking the bank. For example, instead of spending hours searching for the perfect stock footage or music track, you can let the AI system suggest relevant assets based on your input. This not only speeds up the process but also ensures that your videos maintain a consistent style and tone. Increase Customization and Creativity Another significant benefit of using AI video generators is the increased customization they offer. This can limit your ability to experiment with different styles, formats, and ideas. AI video generators break down these barriers by providing a wide range of customization options. Automation in Video Editing and Production One of the most significant features of AI video generators is the automation they bring to the video editing and production process. AI video generators, on the other hand, use machine learning algorithms to automate much of this work, making the editing process faster and more efficient. They can also add subtitles, transitions, and other elements without requiring manual input, saving you valuable time and effort. By integrating these multimedia elements, AI video generators provide a comprehensive solution for creating engaging and high-quality videos. ChatGPT and similar generative AI chatbots are all the talk, but new advancements are particularly exciting when it comes to the use of AI in video production! From voiceover creation to analytics, generative artificial intelligence has the potential to streamline and enhance many aspects of the video production process! AI's impact on video production will grow even more significant as it continues to develop and evolve. However, like most good things, using AI in your video production process also has limitations. In particular, AI has shortcomings in areas that require a more insightful and creative approach. In this blog post, we'll explore the benefits and drawbacks of using AI in video production and discuss where it works best in the overall video production process. Revolutionizing Video Production: How AI Is Changing The Future Artificial Intelligence is likely the future of video production. The expanding use of AI models in video production has been revolutionizing video marketing and the whole video production industry. With AI technology, it's possible to streamline your workflow, improve accuracy, and reduce project turnaround times. Thanks to this powerful tool, your production team can spend more time focusing on creativity and innovation. This extra focus will help ensure unique and captivating videos. Here are some specific areas where AI is positively contributing to video production: SCRIPTWRITING Photographer: Super Snapper | Source: Unsplash Quality scriptwriting is a crucial component of a compelling video. A well-written script will engage and impress your viewers, while a poorly written one can lead to indifference and disengagement. Crafting a script that successfully communicates your message to the right audience allows your video to resonate with viewers and drive action. In recent years, AI has become a fantastic resource for scriptwriting. Using AI in video production can help writers generate new ideas, revise old scripts, craft engaging stories, and even write complex dialogue. AI-powered scriptwriting tools also gather real-time data to help you: Pinpoint your target audience Analyze data from social media, news articles, apps, and other content Identify trends and topics that are relevant and popular Evaluate feedback and provide suggestions for improvement But don't forget about the importance of the human touch! Your audience will quickly recognize a flat AI-generated script, so add some warmth and authenticity to round the edges. Once you have your AI video script, pass it on to a real-life copywriter: They can add some personality and re-write phrases that don't quite make sense. A talented (and human) copywriter can do things AI just can't like: interpret intention and context, make emotional connections, and understand the subtlety and complexity of verbal and non-verbal language. VOICEOVERS A top-notch voiceover for your video creates a polished and professional final product. The voice must have an appropriate tone and style to match the intended message and audience. Scripts and voices should be carefully timed to the video. Producing a well-crafted voiceover ensures an engaging video with which your viewers can connect. Fortunately, AI in video production can quickly and easily create high-quality video voiceovers. Your businesses can save time and resources in the voice-over production process by using AI-powered text-to-speech (TTS) software, machine learning algorithms, and natural language processing (NLP). These tools also help create greater consistency and accuracy in the final product. Utilizing an AI-generated voice-over can do the following: Generate complete voiceovers in a matter of minutes (human voice recordings can take days or weeks) Customize various voices and accents to match any style of video content Adjust parameters such as pitch, volume, and speed to align perfectly with the video Maintain a natural tone, consistent pace, and accurate pronunciation throughout Artificial Intelligence can drastically improve your voiceover's overall quality and professionalism, leading to increased viewer engagement and retention. Just know that while it is an incredibly useful tool, AI isn't perfect. It can't understand flow or intention. Unlike live actors, it lacks the ability to make changes based on interpretation. And sometimes, the voice can sound a little like… well, like a robot imitating a human. TRANSCRIPTS AND SUBTITLES Producing high-quality video transcripts and subtitles ensures your content reaches the widest possible audience. In particular, you'll include viewers with hearing issues, language barriers, and those watching silently. Additionally, you can use this text to put your video content in written formats like blog posts and websites. It's essential, however, to maintain accuracy and clarity because errors can lead to confusion and misinterpretation of your message. AI in video production is a highly efficient way to auto-generate transcripts and subtitles for your videos. A few platforms have actually been using AI systems to transcribe for quite some time. You can accurately transcribe video content and quickly generate subtitles by leveraging deep learning AI algorithms and language processing technology like NLP. AI-powered transcription and captioning services have several significant benefits: Transcribes content in only a few short minutes, saving countless hours Edit and customize AI-generated transcripts and subtitles to quickly meet specific audience needs Improve your video's search engine optimization (SEO) by giving search engines text to crawl and index almost instantly Recognize speech patterns and capture the nuances of language in a once impossible way Keep in mind that you'll still need a sound crew to capture audio elements that AI tools likely won't pick up. For example, AI can't transcribe audio elements that aren't voices, such as sound effects and music. And regarding accuracy, though AI is constantly improving, it's always wise to have a human being review your written content for any mistakes or misspellings. ANALYTICS Photographer: Carlos Muza | Source: Unsplash Analytics tools can provide valuable insights into how viewers engage with video content, including metrics such as view count, engagement rate, and audience retention. By analyzing these metrics, businesses can better understand what video elements are resonating with viewers and what may need to be adjusted. Your content will go further if you use analytics to guide your future video production and marketing strategies. With its ability to process and analyze vast amounts of data quickly and accurately, using AI in video production offers significant potential for improving video marketing analytics and enhancing the effectiveness of video marketing campaigns. One key way is through its ability to track viewer engagement. By analyzing viewer behavior, such as how long they watch a video or which parts they skip, AI can identify useful patterns and trends. Advanced AI analytic tools offer these capabilities: Segment and target audiences based on viewer demographics, interests, and preferences Determine areas of video content that need improvement Suggest changes to titles, keywords, and descriptions using click-through and conversion rates Predict the likely outcomes of video marketing strategies Overall, by leveraging AI capabilities and integrating them into your marketing strategies, you can gain valuable insights into your audience, optimize your video content, and achieve greater success in your marketing efforts. As you can see, AI in video production has the potential to become the ultimate tool in streamlining the video production process_._ But let's be honest; AI isn't a one-size-fits-all solution. AI falls short in some areas, especially those requiring a more nuanced and creative approach. The Limitations Of AI In Video Production: Why Human Input Still Matters Using AI automation for the tedious parts of video production, like transcribing, subtitling, and analytic tasks, frees up time and money for human video editors to focus on more creative and strategic aspects of video production. That's a good thing because AI can't compete with people when it comes to creating concepts and relaying emotions, storyboarding, and even serious editing. Let's look at a few more areas where AI hasn't quite caught up (yet). CREATIVE CONCEPTS While artificial Intelligence is a powerhouse for many aspects of video production, it currently lacks in the creative concept department. This is because the creative process of developing video content usually involves subjective, complex decisions that require human input and creativity. AI "brains" are a filing cabinet of existing facts and data that can be combined for helpful solutions and sometimes "new to us" ideas. Consequently, AI cannot replicate creative vision or intuition. AI can generate visual and audio elements based on predefined parameters. Still, it cannot replace the unique ideas and perspectives that come from human creativity and imagination. Furthermore, the creative conception of videos often involves collaboration and communication between different team members, including writers, designers, and directors. While using AI in video production can streamline certain aspects of this process, such as analyzing feedback data, it cannot replace the value of human collaboration and brainstorming. As a result, AI simply can't help much with the creative conception of videos. Thankfully, the artistic process will continue to rely on human creativity, intuition, and collaboration to develop unique and engaging video content that resonates with audiences. STORYBOARDING Humans may not always have the upper hand on AI, but regarding storyboarding, we definitely have them beat. That's because the storyboarding process involves creativity and intuition, and a profound comprehension of human emotion and motivation. Storyboarding involves visualizing and planning the narrative arc of a video, including the characters, scenes, and dialogue. This requires a deep understanding of the target audience, their preferences, and their emotional responses. While AI can generate insights and analyze data about audience behavior, it cannot replicate the emotional intellect that a human storyboard artist can bring to the table. Moreover, storyboarding often requires making creative decisions based on reasoning and personal perspective. A human storyboard artist can draw on their own experiences and imagination to develop unique and engaging visual elements that capture the essence of your story. AI in video production, on the other hand, can only generate visuals based on data sets, which limits the originality of the final product. Lastly, this process is often collaborative and involves lots of communication and cooperation. A storyboard artist can effectively express their feelings to other team members, developing a cohesive and compelling narrative. At the same time, AI in video production still lacks the ability to engage in thoughtful compromise. EDITING Editing videos involves piecing together the footage, adding music, sound effects, and transitions, and making cuts and adjustments to ensure the final product is exactly as it was envisioned. Good editing can make all the difference in the completed video, as it helps create a more cohesive and engaging narrative and can also enhance the visual and auditory aspects of the video. AI in video production and editing has come a long way. Newer AI capabilities, like quickly and seamlessly merging multiple clips, have eliminated countless hours of human editing and undoubtedly saved many budgets. And while AI is great at tackling basic tasks like motion tracking, color correction, and other technical processes, it has yet to advance enough to replace human editing completely. Skilled editors have a keen eye for detail and understand how to use their tools to create a visually and thematically impactful video that resonates with the target audience. Humans have an innate understanding of the storytelling process and the ability to interpret other people's intentions, like writers and directors. This helps them grasp the overall vision for the video, which is still a relatively abstract concept for Artificial Intelligence. AI in video production has made significant advancements in recent years. However, despite its potential, one of its most significant limitations is its reliance on pre-existing data sets or algorithms. AI only learns and operates within the parameters set by its programming and training data. This can result in videos that feel unoriginal, repetitive, and lacking in personality and human touch, which may not resonate well with the target audience. The Rise Of AI In Video Production: A Game-Changer AI is changing the video production and marketing game, whether we like it or not. Currently, there are many effective ways to use AI in video production. From automating tedious tasks to gaining valuable insights and improving efficiency in the video production process, it has become a great way to save time and money. But with all its benefits, AI simply can not replace the unique human touch and creativity needed to make truly memorable and compelling videos. While AI can handle repetitive tasks like data analysis, basic production, and editing, it needs to catch up in areas that require a more subjective and creative approach. But by leveraging the strengths of AI technology and human creativity together, it’s possible to create innovative and impactful videos more efficiently. September 27, 2024 By Stjepan Alaupovic Creative Director, Clear Online Video Featured Articles How AI Is Transforming the Video Production Landscape Artificial intelligence (AI) is rapidly transforming the video production industry in profound and multifaceted ways. While AI might be controversial in some circles, it is a cultural movement many industries embrace. Some experts have compared the AI rev­olution to the internet and how it changed the modern workplace. No matter your thoughts on AI and the mor­al ethics of computer-generated tools, there is no denying that many industries are rapidly researching how to implement AI within their workforce. For anyone with experience in the video production industry, it has been clear from Day 1 that the tools used to make videos, broadcasts, and movies are constantly chang­ing with technology. Seismic shifts in this in­dustry have always been prevalent, like 4:3 to 16:9 aspect ratios, film to digital, standard definition to high definition, the rise of drones, linear editing to non-linear editing, and movie screens to YouTube. This business has and al­ways will embrace technology. It is easy to get swept up in the allure of AI. Yet, amid the rapid evolution, we must main­tain sight of an essential truth: AI can never replace the human touch. Rather than running away from AI, we can lean into it, learn how to use it to enhance our work, and apply skillful implementation of this technology. Given that context, I want to explore how streaming production professionals can use AI tools. The evolution of AI extends from prepro­duction planning to postproduction enhance­ments, offering tools that augment creativity, efficiency, and precision. It is difficult to ignore all of the buzz about AI these days, but here is what streaming pros can expect from this ear­ly stage of AI technology. Preproduction: Enhanced Planning and Creativity In the initial stages of video production, AI is revolutionizing how we conceptualize and plan our projects. Traditionally, preproduc­tion involves labor-intensive tasks like script­writing, storyboarding, and shot planning. AI-driven tools now assist in automating and op­timizing these processes. Scriptwriting and Storyboarding Most video projects begin with a script, but frequently, it isn’t easy to get the right words onto paper or the screen. Platforms such as ChatGPT, Google’s Gemini, and Microsoft Co­pilot offer tools to get you started with an idea and to generate a full-length script for videos. As with many of these AI tools, I recommend applying a light touch. This means tailoring the AI-generated text with a professional, human quality that speaks directly to your primary au­dience. Video professionals want to sound on-brand when working with clients, so the tools should serve as a starting point rather than generate a final product. On the commercial side, AI-powered plat­forms like ScriptBook analyze existing scripts and predict their advertising viability. They of­fer insights into plot structure, character devel­opment, and potential box office performance. Similarly, tools like Plotagon and Storyboarder.ai leverage AI to help creators generate storyboards quickly, providing visual representa­tions of scripts without requiring manual draw­ing skills. The Storyboarder.ai storyboard generation tool Location Scouting and Scheduling AI assists location scouting by analyzing vast databases of potential shooting sites, con­sidering factors such as lighting conditions, lo­gistical feasibility, and even historical weath­er patterns. Tools like Scenechronize utilize AI for scheduling, ensuring optimal shooting schedules that minimize conflicts and maxi­mize efficiency. Production: Streamlining and Enhancing Creativity AI technologies can streamline operations and enhance creative possibilities during vid­eo production, fundamentally altering how we capture footage. Camera Automation and Robotics AI-powered drones and robotic cameras are increasingly common on sets, providing precise and consistent shots that would be challenging for human operators. These technologies ben­efit complex sequences, such as action scenes or intricate tracking shots. AI algorithms can control these devices, ensuring smooth and stable footage. Real-Time Analytics and Feedback AI offers real-time analytics on set, analyz­ing footage as it’s captured to provide immedi­ate feedback. This capability allows directors and videographers to adjust instantly, ensur­ing that each shot meets the desired criteria. For instance, AI can assess lighting, framing, and even actor performances, suggesting mod­ifications to enhance the final product. Postproduction: Revolutionizing Editing And Effects The most significant impact of AI today is felt in the postproduction phase, where it rev­olutionizes editing, visual effects, and audio enhancement. Automated Editing AI-driven editing software, like Adobe Sen­sei and Blackmagic Design’s DaVinci Resolve, automates time-consuming tasks such as sort­ing through footage, cutting clips, and assem­bling rough cuts. These tools analyze the visual and audio content to make intelligent editing decisions like removing pauses and filler words. This significantly reduces the time required to produce versions for client review and a pol­ished final cut. Visual Effects and CGI Hollywood has a long history of creating movie magic, and AI is making waves in visu­al effects (VFX) and computer-generated imag­ery (CGI). Deep learning algorithms can create stunning VFX with minimal human interven­tion. Tools like Deep Art Effects and Artisto transform video footage by applying artistic styles, while platforms like Runway ML enable creators to quickly generate realistic CGI char­acters and environments. Deep Art Effects is an AI-powered visual effects engine Audio Enhancement AI also enhances audio postproduction. Platforms like Auphonic use AI to balance audio levels, remove background noise, and ensure consistent sound quality across different scenes. Voice synthesis and dubbing tools like Descript and Lyrebird allow for seamless voiceovers and dialogue replacements, maintaining natural intonation and emotional resonance. Auphonic is an AI-driven audio post-production tool Adobe Premiere Pro released AI enhance­ment features built within the essential sound panel to aid in repairing poor-quality audio. The results can turn almost unusable source audio into something near podcast quality. AI-driven sound enhancement features in Adobe Premiere Pro Distribution and Audience Engagement Beyond the production process, AI is reshap­ing how videos are distributed and how audi­ences engage with content. Personalized Content Recommendations AI algorithms drive content recommenda­tion engines on platforms like YouTube, Netflix, and Amazon Prime. By analyzing viewer be­havior and preferences, these algorithms sug­gest videos that are more likely to resonate with individual users, increasing engagement and viewership. Interactive and Immersive Experiences AI is at the forefront of creating interactive and immersive video experiences. Virtual real­ity (VR) and augmented reality (AR) technolo­gies powered by AI offer viewers unparalleled engagement. These experiences are not just passive; they invite viewers to participate, mak­ing the content more memorable and impactful. Content Localization AI-powered translation and dubbing tools make localizing content for global audiences easier. Platforms like Papercup and Deepdub use AI to translate dialogue and synchronize lip movements with the translated audio, en­suring a seamless viewing experience for non-native speakers. Vimeo Enterprise introduced a set of AI tools for users to translate videos at scale. Publishers can quickly and easily translate videos to un­lock global markets, train international teams, and foster an inclusive workplace. The feature allows videos to address global audiences in dozens of languages, with each new audio and caption translation added to the player for view­ers to choose from. Vimeo for Enterprise now includes AI-based caption and dialogue translation tools. The Future of AI in Video Production As we look ahead, the integration of AI into video production is poised to deepen, with sev­eral exciting developments on the horizon. Enhanced Collaboration AI will facilitate more efficient collaboration among production teams. Cloud-based plat­forms powered by AI will enable real-time col­laboration on projects, allowing team members to work together seamlessly, regardless of their physical location. This capability is particular­ly relevant in a post-pandemic world where re­mote work is increasingly common. Predictive Analytics and Decision Making AI will play a crucial role in predictive ana­lytics, helping producers make informed deci­sions about everything from casting and mar­keting to distribution strategies. By analyzing vast amounts of data, AI can predict trends and audience preferences, guiding production choices that are more likely to succeed. Ethical and Creative Considerations As AI becomes more integrated into video production, ethical and creative considerations will emerge. Issues such as deepfake technol­ogy, intellectual property rights, and the bal­ance between automation and human creativi­ty will need to be addressed. The industry must establish guidelines and best practices to en­sure that AI is used responsibly and ethically. AI is undeniably transforming the video pro­duction industry, offering tools and capabilities that enhance creativity, efficiency, and preci­sion. From preproduction planning to postpro­duction enhancements, AI is reshaping every aspect of the process. As we embrace these technologies, we must remain mindful of the ethical and creative implications, ensuring that AI is a valuable ally in the pursuit of storytelling. The future of video production is bright, and AI will play a central role in shaping its evolution. While AI will streamline many facets of the video production industry, I want to remind readers that human connection is rooted in em­pathy, intuition, and the subtle nuances of emo­tion. Algorithms or lines of code cannot repli­cate these elements. In the realm of creativity too, the human touch remains irreplaceable. While AI can mimic styles and generate content, it lacks the depth of feeling and the unique perspective that define genuinely great art. Our creativity is not just a product of logic and data; it’s born from our struggles, joys, and existence. Ultimately, AI can enhance our lives, provid­ing tools to ease our burdens and expand our capabilities. However, it’s crucial to remember that it is just that—a tool. Our experiences go beyond the reach of AI. As we move forward, let’s embrace technology while remembering that it cannot replace us.
